qas.question: How many distinct rounds of genome duplication events are suspected in the evolution of seed plants?
When did the first whole genome duplication event occur?
What type of event perhaps created the line which led to modern flowering plants?

answers.text: by sequencing the genome of an ancient flowering plant

plausible_answers.text: two distinct rounds of whole genome duplication events

qas.question: What appears to be the cause of duplicaton of seed plants?
When did Darwin's "abominable mystery first appear?
When was the ancient plant used in the study dated to?
Who coined the term duplication event?

context: The evolution of seed plants and later angiosperms appears to be the result of <a0_0><b5_0>two<a0_0/> distinct rounds of whole genome duplication events<b5_0/>. These occurred at <a1_0><b6_0>319 million years ago<b6_0/><a1_0/> and 192 million years ago. Another possible <a2_0>whole genome duplication<a2_0/> event at <b7_0>160 million years ago<b7_0/> perhaps created the ancestral line that led to all modern flowering plants. That event was studied <a3_0>by <b8_0>sequencing the genome<b8_0/> of an ancient flowering plant<a3_0/>, Amborella trichopoda, and directly addresses <a4_0><b9_0>Darwin<b9_0/><a4_0/>'s "abominable mystery."
